job_title: Support Worker in High Wycombe, England
pros: The support workers are the heart and soul of the company and the individuals you support are amazing
cons: Toxic management all the way up. Unsupportive and have not changed for years making it one of the worst companies to work for. Many staff cry and leave after expressing the same views.

job_title: Residential Support Worker in Wingrave, England
pros: The young people you work with are what makes the job
cons: Staff really care about the young people but the service is understaffed and underfunded meaning the young people don't get the care they deserve and staff saftey can be put at risk. If you work full time you are expected to still work once your shift is over while waiting for other staff.

job_title: Support Worker in Milton Keynes, England

job_title: Educational Support Worker in Milton Keynes, England
pros:
- The learners we supported. Working with them every day helped me develop so much as a person. I supported many different learners in a variety of settings (at home, in the community, in college etc.), and each of them were amazing.

- The staff. All of my colleagues were genuinely nice people and a delight to work with.

- The manager. Although young, she was professional, approachable, and fair. She knew the right thing to do in every situation and was clearly very knowledgable in this industry.

- Good hours (9-5, unusual for a job in the care industry).

- Really interesting and varied job. You're not just in one building every day doing the same thing.
cons: - Poor pay. I do understand that this is typical of the charity sector as funding is difficult to come by. However, many of the employees had university degrees so the pay really wasn't ideal.

job_title: Support Worker in Bury, North West England, England
pros: Rewarding company to work for, they train you well. Support for a variety of people with learning disabilities.
cons: A good place to work for but the pay could be worse, but it could be a lot better too. Similar for at the time of a.g. Xmas bonusses.

review_title: Expanding charity but ignores the welfare of its staff on ground level.
job_title: in Brighton, England
pros: The people you support. The staff who work hard to keep people safe and happy despite staff shortages and rubbish wage.
cons: The lies about pay increase. Pay risen because of minimum wage going up nothing to do with MacIntyre doing the right thing and paying a living wage. Now staff that have been there a long time are closer in wage to new staff. No incentive. Sleeps have been 27 quid for years.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oxford, England
pros: Overall good staff team, but their good will is taken advantage of by poor managers.
cons:
Low pay, no pay rise for years.
Managers don’t have a clue, no people skills.
Some staff are treated better than others, same for people they support.
Sickness policy brought in meant that staff get no pay for 3 days, so forcing staff to come in when unwell or unfit for work.
Staff told to agree to policy or leave (basically)
Managers bending the terms of contracts to suit themselves.
Ignoring comments from staff, safety of staff disregarded.

job_title: Support Worker in Ringwood, England
pros: Love to support people with learning disability living in their own home
cons: I’m going to move to new accommodation which is far from MacIntyre
